reviewText: Most of the negative reviews here are because of technical issues that are solvable on most systems. Fullscreen works by pressing ALT+Enter (maybe not while in the menu or title screen or cutscene, but ingame), widescreen support is available via a hack. On some systems, the resolution may be limited to 640x480 or 800x600, but that is not the normal behaviour. You should get the highest 4:3 resolution closest to your native resolution without a patch. XBox controllers are not officially supported because this game uses directinput for controller support, which is the predecessor to xinput. If you have one of the recent Logitech gamepads (F310 for example), you can choose between directinput and xinput via a hardware switch on the controller, then map the controller keys correctly (setup controller) and the game works out of the box. If you have to use an xbox compatible controller, you have to fiddle around to get the trigger keys working. This is because the trigger keys are analog and on the same axis on the xbox compatible controllers, but are two seperate digital keys on the older standard. Please note that this game was developed before the xbox compatible controllers had been invented! It would have been nice of Capcom to have this version revamped like they did for PS3 and XBox, but they have not.  It is not optimized for the PC and it is an old game, but I still think it is awesome.

before you read my review or buy the game remember DMC3 is a amazing game I highly suggest you buy it, I have bought it three times now but DON'T buy the pc version if you don't want to tear your hair out in frustration but more of that later.

Lets start the actual review now shall we?

First the story - The story takes place a few years before the first devil may cry, Dante who has yet to pick a name for his shop is just hanging around when a man named Arkham enters and tells Dante his brother has a invitation for him. Dante is then attacked by lessor demons but quickly (and stylishly) kills them all and this starts the events of the game and overall the story is pretty good best in the series has some insane motioncapture and good voice acting (compared to DMC1 and DmC this is oscar worthy)


Second the styles - You can choose between four different styles which are Swordmaster where your melee weapons have more moves, do more damage and let you combo in the air easily, Gunslinger lets you use your guns in extremely stylish ways from spinning in mid air while fireing down to curb stomping a demon while shooting him in the head and its a pleasure to watch the animations, Royalguard works as a block button but it doesn't stop there sure you can block and take reduced damage but if you perfectly time your block you can absorb all damage and release it in a extremely damaging attack that if you build enough damage up you can instant kill some of the tougher demons, Trickster gives you another type of dodge, a teleport, a air dash and the ability to run on walls, Trickster can be used to create insane combos if you know what you're doing. There are two other styles quicksilver and doppleganger which let you slow down time and create a copy of yourself and thats about it but if used right are deadly (doppleganger unlocks a hidden two player mode to)


Third the combat - The combat in this game is insanely fun with a total of 5 devil arms (melee weapons) and 5 fire arms (guns) for Dante and the ability to bring any combination of weapons (two devil arms two fire arms) and one of 6 styles to choose from this game has a crazy ammount of depth in its combat especailly since all weapons and styles (except doppleganger and quicksilver) can be upgraded and gain more moves.


Fourth Extras - With the special edition you are able to play as Vergil who has 3 devil arms and no fire arms but shoots summond swords instead and a single style (he has less depth then Dante but is fun to play) After you beat the game once you can start a new game as Vergil you will be given a cutscene that takes place before DMC3 but don't get your hopes up he ends up going through the same levels as Dante (from the Devil May Cry all the way to hell) The style switcher mod does work on Vergil but you can only use dark slayer (Default style) and Dante's quicksilver style (due to the other styles not working right or them already being a part of Dark Slayer)

Fifth should you buy it - In short yes you should buy this game...... if you have a playstation 2 the pc version is a extremely bad port and it is fixable (I fixed it after spending over 10 hours configureing it) it just takes a lot of time and a lot of reading user guides on how to fix it. On the brightside of the pc version is the ability to mod and the famous style switcher mod (go get it now) which lets you change to any of the 6 styles at any time in game without having to stop at a statue to change them (it also comes with other features that let you customize the game further but I won't get into that)

If you use a controller be prepared to break it in half with your teeth out of pure rage when you find out the triggers don't work and the sticks are reversed (right stick moves you left stick turns camera) there are fixes for this but they don't always work and if you are useing Motioninjoy be prepared to just quit (I made a discussion post on how to fix a ps3 controller with motioninjoy but if you are useing any other controllers good luck to you)

I also hope you have a somewhat decent computer cause this game runs like hell the framerate is subpar and requires you to delete audio files (really?) to get the framerate up but it stops the badass soundtrack from playing if you do so (luckly for me my computer can handle it)


Final - Do i recommend this game? again yes if you can get a console copy or if you are willing to spend 10+ hours fixing it, if you have no choice but to buy it on PC buy it when it goes on sale it usualy drops down to $7.50 but this is one of my favorite games of all time it just has a bad pc port

a simple but enjoyable story, and more importantly you get to beat the crap out of demons while being a total
badass. (Also it's pretty challenging so, if you don't like handholding- this is the game for you)

I've had and played this game for about 4 years now, and still love it dearly. (Although it only says 30 hours on Steam, I also played it a lot on PS3 later).
But recently I came to notice how low the Steam ratings for this game were, and I read through the reviews to see why.
From what I've seen, it's all in regards to the port itself, which is understandable.
I've personally never had a problem running the game on Steam (even without downloading patches or anything).

That said, I do think that the in-game references to the controls are complete jank, because they are based on a
numbering system for buttons that VERY unclear. This can be solved by a simple google search to see what each button
does. I don't think the frame-rate is optimal (especially for a hack and slash) but it's not unplayable,
I really didn't notice it all that much when I first got into the game, but only after I'd had my share of a variety
of hack and slash games and really came to know the genre, did I notice the difference.
I also never had a problem using a controller as the controller scheme menu is actually pretty easy to understand,
although customization is a bit annoying.

In summary:
I guess from my experience, I'd say the game is still worth is, especially during Steam Sales, assuming that you can run it.
Like I said, it is a bit jank here and there, and it's not an excellent port by any means, but if you are looking to have a
hack and slash game that's easy to run on most computers just to casually play whenever, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Devil May Cry 3 is a great game, do not get me wrong.

This version however, is bloody awful. Framerate hovers around 30 at the best of times -- other versions maintain a stable 60 -- and this can drop when certain enemies appear. I've heard this is something to do with the music files, but I shouldn't have to fart around with deleting or renaming files just to get a game to run as it was supposed to.

Gameplay-wise though, DMC3 has a massive and in-depth combat system that includes lots of small details -- and even lets you do things that were in cutscenes! Not every thing from every cutscene, but a considerable amount of them are indeed doable. Dante handles rather well, and although the Style System is a little limited in this game compared to Devil May Cry 4, the time lapse between the two - enough for Dante to go from cocky, though out of his depth straight through to a marvelous drunken uncle who quite frankly has zero f**ks to give - can be seen as a handwave from the technical reasons for limiting the Style system as such.

My advice? Skip this version, and either get the original PS2 version of the Special Edition, or if you're running a PS3 or 360 in HD, just get the HD Collection. If you get the HD Collection and you're running in SD, you may have some audio synch problems during cutscenes. Also, get DMC4's PC version. Don't let the Games for Windows Live fool you, it's the best version by a long shot, including unique content.

reviewText:
This game is a broken port of the console version. Very badly made without thinking from the perspective of the PC player control ergonomics either using keyboard or gamepad.

GRAPHICS
The graphics are typical of the older Play Station games (think of Resident Evil 2 and 3, except that background buildings are also in 3D). It's dated for 2015, but nothing sinful from when it was originally released.

But the sinful thing in here is that there is no fullscreen mode. It can only be viewed in windowed mode. Max resolution is at 1600x1200. (Even DOS games has fullscreen).

SOUND
It's ok. From the intro to the rock tunes of the (in-game) broken jukebox, it does fine. Positional audio was not used.

CONTROLS
It's a bad port mainly because the control scheme is unbearably bad... keyboard or XBox controller.

With the keyboard, you can configure the key map. The problem with using the keyboard is that [Jump] is reflected as [Style Action]. Pressing [Style Action] is still [Style Action]. I can't make Dante jump.

Buttons can also be configured with the XBox controller... except for the directional movement which is unfortunately placed to the Right analog stick. Forget about no rumble feature. I just want to move the character properly, which I can't.

GAMEPLAY
It has a lot of potential and I can feel that this could have been a good game. Camera control poorly done as well, though. I can only reset the camera view to it's default location. I can't do anything else with it.

OVERALL
I can't even play it, so I can't recommend it at all. The DMC franchise has gone a long way, but unless they've made the controls better, it is probably best to play the older parts of the franchise in the console rather than the PC.

reviewText:
Devil May Cry 3 is probably my favourite action/hack n slash game of all time.  I had the special edition on the ps 2 about 9 years ago, and i loved it like a small angel that fell from heaven.

This port, however, is a worthless, broken and disgraceful sham.  If you've got a console, get the Devil May Cry HD edition instead.  If, like me, your a solo pc gamer, there's no way to get the full goodness of this game, even with all the mods.

First, the controls are broken.  You can kind of get it to work with mods, but as far as i'm aware you can't get the shoulder buttons (lt and rt) to work, and you actually need them.  I also couldn't get my second analog stick to work the camera, which makes the game most unenjoyable as you can't adjust the camera manually.  I could kind of deal with that, but...

The framerate is awful.  This is a 2005 ps2 game which stutters and grinds down to abysmal rates on a PC that easily handles Skyrim.  You can fix it by deleting select audion files, apparantly, but left with the choice of losing audio or tolerating a crappy framerate, i choose to just uninstall it and leave my memories untarnished.

If you've got a console, get the HD collection. You might also want to try Devil May Cry 4, which is a much better and all round pretty sweet PC port (though sadly an inferior game),  If you get this on pc, be aware that you are buying a woefully grim port of classic.

reviewText:
Great Game, highly recomended...

...but not on PC.

This is one of the best action titles you could ever play, and is arguably the best game in the series. The combat system is one of the deepest in any game, and it ranks you on how well you can perform combos. It has a lot of unlockables, including Vergil as a playable character, so there is also a lot of replay value in the game.

Unfortunately, though, the PC port is horrible, one of the worst ever made. The game was released back in 2006 on PC's and it still gives even some of the higher end PC's performance issues. The reason behind the poor performance is the music of all things. The game also lacks controller support, so you're forced to use the keyboard and mouse to play the game. There is a survival guide thread that tells you how to fix the problems, but there are a few third party downloads that have to be made, and even then, success isn't guaranteed for everyone.

In the end, the game is just a very poor port of an otherwise amazing game. If you are interested in the game, buy either the original version of the game on the PlayStation 2, or the Devil May Cry HD Collection on the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360. Those have none of the issues that the PC version has.

With a little bit of effort and the Style Switcher mod, this title is a great alternative to the PS2 version.  This is still one of my favorite action games to date, and the gameplay is still challenging.  However, you will have to do some work if you want it to work.

It's made even more dynamic with the ability to expand on Virgil and switch styles on the fly (using mods).

For those who have never played a Devil May Cry title, this is arguably the best of them all.  Though there's options to start on Easy, the game can become extremely challenging.  Once you clear one difficulty, the next one is unlocked.  The hardest difficulty gets extremely hard with more enemies in each level, faster enemies that deal more damage, bosses with fatal (or near) attacks, and if you don't clear enemies quickly, the become much harder to kill.

I think this is one of Capcom's best titles, even though the voice-acting and cutscenes are corny.  Controller extremely highly recommended.

reviewText:
A stylish fighting game classic. This may be considered the peak of the Devil May Cry series. It is also out for quite the while now, so it seems hardly necessary to go into too much detail that has already been covered over and over again.
Storywise, you battle your way through an ancient tower to face your brother Vergil and foil his sinister intentions... but whose plan is really in action here?
Gameplaywise, this game really shines. You can achieve mastery in four styles with different foci (Gunslinger, Swordmaster, Trickster and Royal Guard), plus two slightly more gimmick-like unlockables. You acquire an arsenal of five melee and five long range weapons, each category of which you can equip two and seamlessly switch between them. This is hardly astonishing nowadays, but it still blends together magnificently. There is also the bloody palace, an arena mode that provides slaughter aplenty.
This version comes with new difficulty modes (compared to the original on PS2), which may or may not be of interest to you, and with a playable Vergil. This is a fun variant of the fighting gameplay, but does not introduce a lot of new content otherwise - the levels are simply the campaign all over again, minus the story cutscenes.
One thing that should be mentioned is the optimization of the steam version. I bought the game in retail originally, and there were quite a few problems with it not recognizing gamepads correctly or at all - I ended up with a JoyToKey-workaround, which rather nullified the use of analog sticks, and still had trouble mapping the controller because some buttons were not registered, some double, and some of the in-game controls refused to be changed. The steam game comes with a controller configuration application, a nice little thing that took all this work away and actually succeeded in using both sticks and the various seemingly problematic buttons. This little addition increases playability a good deal for me.

If you do not have this game yet and care for action / (sword-) fighting games with a really well thought-through combat system, I highly recommend looking into this.

reviewText:
A stylish fighting game classic. This may be considered the peak of the Devil May Cry series. It is also out for quite the while now, so it seems hardly necessary to go into too much detail that has already been covered over and over again.
Storywise, you battle your way through an ancient tower to face your brother Vergil and foil his sinister intentions... but whose plan is really in action here?
Gameplaywise, this game really shines. You can achieve mastery in four styles with different foci (Gunslinger, Swordmaster, Trickster and Royal Guard), plus two slightly more gimmick-like unlockables. You acquire an arsenal of five melee and five long range weapons, each category of which you can equip two and seamlessly switch between them. This is hardly astonishing nowadays, but it still blends together magnificently. There is also the bloody palace, an arena mode that provides slaughter aplenty.
This version comes with new difficulty modes (compared to the original on PS2), which may or may not be of interest to you, and with a playable Vergil. This is a fun variant of the fighting gameplay, but does not introduce a lot of new content otherwise - the levels are simply the campaign all over again, minus the story cutscenes.
One thing that should be mentioned is the optimization of the steam version. I bought the game in retail originally, and there were quite a few problems with it not recognizing gamepads correctly or at all - I ended up with a JoyToKey-workaround, which rather nullified the use of analog sticks, and still had trouble mapping the controller because some buttons were not registered, some double, and some of the in-game controls refused to be changed. The steam game comes with a controller configuration application, a nice little thing that took all this work away and actually succeeded in using both sticks and the various seemingly problematic buttons. This little addition increases playability a good deal for me.

If you do not have this game yet and care for action / (sword-) fighting games with a really well thought-through combat system, I highly recommend looking into this.

reviewText:
Often regarded by long time DMC fans as the best all around DMC title, I can agree that it is very well put together and a hell of a lot of fun. While DMC4 is easier to get into, and more polished in both the gameplay and graphics department - it's no reason to overlook this game. DMC3 is arguably more difficult, and boasts a larger total weapon set along with what is in my opinion a much better setting and theme (very much Castlevania esque). In DMC3:SE you are also granted the ability to play as Dante's twin brother Vergil, who presents a very different and equally fun playstyle. There are also more total styles available for Dante, including Quicksilver (slow time) and Doppleganger (second Dante that repeats moves you do)

Fast paced combat filled with many combos and mechanics, along with a sizable amount of content and replayability, it makes for an overall fun experience that gets better as you do.

My only problem is the fact that the base port is very poorly done. KB&M controls are quite awful, and game performance has a tendency to drop even on a powerful rig for seemingly no reason (I mean, it's a PS2 era game on modern hardware).

Regardless, highly recommended for fans of action and fighting games. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Often regarded by long time DMC fans as the best all around DMC title, I can agree that it is very well put together and a hell of a lot of fun. While DMC4 is easier to get into, and more polished in both the gameplay and graphics department - it's no reason to overlook this game. DMC3 is arguably more difficult, and boasts a larger total weapon set along with what is in my opinion a much better setting and theme (very much Castlevania esque). In DMC3:SE you are also granted the ability to play as Dante's twin brother Vergil, who presents a very different and equally fun playstyle. There are also more total styles available for Dante, including Quicksilver (slow time) and Doppleganger (second Dante that repeats moves you do)

Fast paced combat filled with many combos and mechanics, along with a sizable amount of content and replayability, it makes for an overall fun experience that gets better as you do.

My only problem is the fact that the base port is very poorly done. KB&M controls are quite awful, and game performance has a tendency to drop even on a powerful rig for seemingly no reason (I mean, it's a PS2 era game on modern hardware).

Regardless, highly recommended for fans of action and fighting games. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Let me start this review by saying I didn't play this game anywhere near launch (started only recently), and have had very little experience with the Devil May Cry series before I started playing this game. I did have experience playing God of War, Ninja Gaiden Sigma and the like before however, so I'm familiar with the Hack & Slash genre.

With that said, here is my review. You're free to disagree with my points (I'd be more glad if you did agree though :)) as this is my personal opinion.

First of all, the story. I kinda liked it, although it wasn't unusually gripping or emotional.  I don't want to spoil anything to people who haven't played it yet, but I will say that thanks to Dante's entertaining persona, the memorable bosses, and a few nice plot twists I didn't expect, it's one of the better plots for this type of game I came across. 7/10

The gameplay. This game has the best combat I've ever seen in this type of game, with great flow, especially on Turbo mode. Trying out different load-outs (there are plenty of combinations of arms, and most weapons are unique and fun to use) and styles (essentially a selectable special move to go along with your weapons) is addicting, and enemies (bosses in particular) are varied and require different strategies rather than repetitive mashing or QTEs to beat (looking at you, God of War).
Exploration and puzzles were a bit too simplistic for me most of the time, but helped make this game feel more like a grand adventure than a static arena.
The controls in the game however are problematic. While I've got them to work perfectly with my Logitech F310 (in D-Input mode) and Net Way PS3/PC Gamepad, This game doesn't support Xbox 360 and One controllers without some tweaking, so I recommend having an older, Direct-Input controller to play with as Keyboards aren't optimal for this type of game. 10/10 (with a gamepad, otherwise 6. yeah, it's that important)

The graphics of the game are showing their age; it is a relatively old game, and doesn't support high resolutions. Also, the graphics of this version are inferior to the PS2 and HD Collection versions as some of the more advanced lighting and shadowing effects are missing, and there is some very mild lag in some areas. The game is still perfectly fun and playable with these faults, but it's still something to keep in mind though if you care a lot about visuals. Trying out different load-outs (there are plenty of combinations of arms, and most weapons are unique and fun to use) and styles (essentially a selectable special move to go along with your weapons) is addicting, and enemies (bosses in particular) are varied and require different strategies rather than repetitive mashing or QTEs to beat (looking at you, God of War).
Exploration and puzzles were a bit too simplistic for me most of the time, but helped make this game feel more like a grand adventure than a static arena.
The controls in the game however are problematic. While I've got them to work perfectly with my Logitech F310 (in D-Input mode) and Net Way PS3/PC Gamepad, This game doesn't support Xbox 360 and One controllers without some tweaking, so I recommend having an older, Direct-Input controller to play with as Keyboards aren't optimal for this type of game. 10/10 (with a gamepad, otherwise 6. yeah, it's that important)

The graphics of the game are showing their age; it is a relatively old game, and doesn't support high resolutions. Also, the graphics of this version are inferior to the PS2 and HD Collection versions as some of the more advanced lighting and shadowing effects are missing, and there is some very mild lag in some areas. The game is still perfectly fun and playable with these faults, but it's still something to keep in mind though if you care a lot about visuals. (6.5/10, although if you like the battle themes you might give an 8 or a 9)

reviewText:
Let me start this review by saying I didn't play this game anywhere near launch (started only recently), and have had very little experience with the Devil May Cry series before I started playing this game. I did have experience playing God of War, Ninja Gaiden Sigma and the like before however, so I'm familiar with the Hack & Slash genre.

With that said, here is my review. You're free to disagree with my points (I'd be more glad if you did agree though :)) as this is my personal opinion.

First of all, the story. I kinda liked it, although it wasn't unusually gripping or emotional.  I don't want to spoil anything to people who haven't played it yet, but I will say that thanks to Dante's entertaining persona, the memorable bosses, and a few nice plot twists I didn't expect, it's one of the better plots for this type of game I came across. 7/10

The gameplay. This game has the best combat I've ever seen in this type of game, with great flow, especially on Turbo mode. Trying out different load-outs (there are plenty of combinations of arms, and most weapons are unique and fun to use) and styles (essentially a selectable special move to go along with your weapons) is addicting, and enemies (bosses in particular) are varied and require different strategies rather than repetitive mashing or QTEs to beat (looking at you, God of War).
Exploration and puzzles were a bit too simplistic for me most of the time, but helped make this game feel more like a grand adventure than a static arena.
The controls in the game however are problematic. While I've got them to work perfectly with my Logitech F310 (in D-Input mode) and Net Way PS3/PC Gamepad, This game doesn't support Xbox 360 and One controllers without some tweaking, so I recommend having an older, Direct-Input controller to play with as Keyboards aren't optimal for this type of game. 10/10 (with a gamepad, otherwise 6. yeah, it's that important)

The graphics of the game are showing their age; it is a relatively old game, and doesn't support high resolutions. Also, the graphics of this version are inferior to the PS2 and HD Collection versions as some of the more advanced lighting and shadowing effects are missing, and there is some very mild lag in some areas. The game is still perfectly fun and playable with these faults, but it's still something to keep in mind though if you care a lot about visuals. The character and environment designs however were pretty good for their time, and still have a bit of charm, even today. (7/10)

The music here is a mixed bag: I'm not a fan of the heavy-metal esque battle themes, although they fit the setting of the game. The rest of the music, like ambient sounds and effects are immersive however, and the goddess statue and final boss themes were very nice IMO. (6.5/10, although if you like the battle themes you might give an 8 or a 9)

Finally replayability. This game isn't very long (about 12 hours for my first playthrough) but has immense replay value, with a lot of harder difficulty levels to unlock and test your skills with, an alternate playable character with unique weapons (Vergil), the ability to carry your upgrades and items from playthrough to playthrough, and the Bloody Palace, an arena with near endless battles, this game can keep you busy for a very long time if you want to master it. 10/10.

Verdict: DMC3 SE is a fantastic game, with a ton of replay value. If you have a gamepad and don't mind a minor graphical downgrade, this is a solid reccomendation. If you're with a keyboard though or want the best graphics available, I'd recommend getting the PS2 version/HD remake if you can. Even if you can't, there's still a very solid game here. (No final score, as there are too many variables depending on your hardware and everyone has their own priorities in games. I only try to advise. Who am I to judge what you find important?)
